title.fr-CA: Prsentation

content1.en-CA:
People with disabilities who live in Saskatchewan and who meet the necessary age, financial, and medical eligibility requirements may be eligible for the Saskatchewan Assured Income for Disability (SAID) benefits. The SAID benefits provide financial assistance to those who qualify.

Each step involved in the application process for the SAID benefits will be described in detail in this guide.
content1.fr-CA:
Les personnes ayant un handicap qui rsident en Saskatchewan qui remplissent les critres dge, financiers et mdicaux admissibles pourraient avoir droit aux prestations du revenu assur pour personnes handicapes de la Saskatchewan (SAID). Les prestations du revenu assur pour personnes handicapes de la Saskatchewan offrent de laide financire  ceux qui sont admissibles.

Le guide dcrira en dtail chaque tape du processus de demande pour les prestations du revenu assur pour personnes handicapes de la Saskatchewan.

content2.en-CA:
### If you are approved to receive the Saskatchewan Assured Income for Disability (SAID) you could receive

- Between $961 - $1,094 for a living income benefit, depending on where in Saskatchewan you live
- Up to $114 for specific utilities
- $93 for energy or home heating
- $50 for water and sewer

### I am Indigenous. Is the journey different for me?

If you are Indigenous and are living on reserve, you have to access Federal funding distributed by the Band. If you are Indigenous and live off reserve, you can access provincial funding through the SAID program.

content3.en-CA:
### I am Indigenous. Is the journey different for me?

If you are Indigenous and are living on reserve, you have to access Federal funding distributed by the Band. If you are Indigenous and live off reserve, you can access provincial funding through the SAID program.
content3.fr-CA:
### Je suis autochtone. Le processus est-il diffrent pour moi?

Si vous tes autochtone et que vous rsidez dans une rserve, vous devez accder aux fonds fdraux distribus par la bande. Si vous tes autochtone et que vous rsidez en dehors de la rserve, vous pouvez accder  un financement provincial par le biais du programme du SAID.

title.fr-CA: Admissibilit

content1.en-CA:
## Age requirement

To apply for SAID benefits, you must be at least 18 years of age.

## Financial requirements

You must lack financial resources to provide for your basic needs to be eligible to receive SAID benefits. Basic needs include things like shelter, food, and utilities. The exact amount you will receive in SAID benefits will depend on any additional income you receive and any assets you own.

## Assets

When you apply for SAID benefits, the intake worker will review all of your assets. You can have up to $1,500 in liquid assets if you are a single person. Some assets are exempt, some are partially exempt, and some are not exempt. Liquid assets can include things such as:

- Money in bank accounts
- Registered retirement savings plans (RRSP)
- Bonds
- Investment certificates

Your real assets and personal assets will be exempt from being considered when calculating your total liquid assets.

## Fully Deductible Income

Some types of income will be subtracted from your monthly SAID benefit. These types of income are called fully deductible income. Fully deductible income includes:

- Child support payments
- Pensions (excluding the Saskatchewan Pension Plan)
- Training and employment allowances
- Employment insurance

## Partially Deductible Income

Some types of income will be partially subtracted from your monthly SAID benefit. These types of income are called partially deductible income. Partially deductible income includes:

- Wages
- Income from room rentals, boarders, or renters
- Gambling gains, lottery winnings, bingo winnings
- Gifts or cash

## Non-Deductible or Exempt Income

Some types of income will not be subtracted from your monthly SAID benefits. These types of income are called non-deductible income or exempt income. Non-deductible income includes:

- Child Tax Benefit
- Saskatchewan Employment Supplement
- Rental Housing Supplement
- Income tax refunds
- GST rebates
- Registered Disability Savings Plan (RDSP)

## Earned Income Exemption

There is a limit to the amount of income you can receive and still be eligible to receive SAID benefits. This is called the Earned Income Exemption. If you are single, you receive up to $6,000 from other sources. If you earn more than your Earned Income Exemption amount, the extra amount you earned will be deducted from your SAID benefits. For example, if you earned $6,050 in one year, $50 would be deducted from your SAID benefits.

## Disability requirement

To be eligible for SAID benefits, you must have a significant and enduring disability. This disability must substantially impact your activities of daily living, which will require you to be assisted by an assistive device, another person, a service animal, or another form of accommodation.

As part of your application, you will complete a Disability Impact Assessment, which will help identify whether you meet the criteria for having a significant and enduring disability.

title.fr-CA: Prsenter une demande

content1.en-CA:
Here are the steps you can follow to apply for SAID benefits. Click Start step 1 at the bottom of this page. This will take you to step one.  At the bottom of each page there will be a Next button you can click once you have completed that step. If you have already completed a step, you can skip it. Go ahead and start by clicking on the step where you would like to start.

You can go through the steps at your own pace. If you need help at any step, go to the Help page to find out where you can get support with your application.
content1.fr-CA:
Voici les tapes  suivre pour dposer une demande de prestations du SAID. Cliquez sur Commencer ltape 1 en bas de cette page. Cela vous dirigera  ltape 1.  Vous trouverez un bouton Suivant en bas de chaque page, vous pouvez cliquer dessus une fois que vous avez termin cette tape. Si vous avez dj rempli une tape, vous pouvez la passer. Allez-y et commencez en cliquant sur l'tape o vous souhaitez commencer.

Vous pouvez suivre les tapes  votre propre rythme. Si vous avez besoin d'aide  n'importe quelle tape, consultez la page Aide pour savoir o vous pouvez obtenir de l'aide pour votre demande.

title.en-CA: After you apply  approved or denied
title.fr-CA: Aprs avoir dpos une demande - approuve ou refuse

content2Title.en-CA: What happens when your application is approved?
content2Title.fr-CA: Que se passe-t-il lorsque votre demande est approuve?

content2.en-CA:
If your application is approved, you will be assigned to work with an Assured Income Specialist, and you will begin receiving SAID benefits. If you were receiving temporary SAID benefits, this will be replaced by the full SAID benefits. The SAID benefits can include:

- Between $805 - $1,064 for a living income benefit, depending on where in Saskatchewan you live
- Up to $114 for specific utilities
- $93 for energy or home heating
- $50 for water and sewer

### How is income determined?

If your application has been approved, you have already provided details about your income. This will be used to determine the benefits you will receive. If your income changes, make sure to complete the [Change in income form](https://publications.saskatchewan.ca/api/v1/products/101650/formats/112374/download) and email the completed form to income.supportss@gov.sk.ca.

Remember, if you are employed, you have a total Income Exemption of up to $6,000 per calendar year if you are a single person without dependents. If you reach your income exemption for the year and you make over your allotted SAID benefits two months in a row, you will be taken off of SAID benefits and can reapply again in January. When you reapply, they will ensure you are financially eligible, but you do not have to complete the Disability Impact Assessment again.

### Participation Planning

Participation planning is a voluntary activity your Assured Income Specialist will ask you if you want to do. This activity is a way to set personal goals and may help find other programs or services that will help you. If you choose not to participate, it will not impact the benefits you receive.

### Individual Employment Plan

If you have a spouse who is able to work full-time, they may be required to find a job and sign an Individual Employment Plan. Your Assured Income Specialist will help you and your spouse develop the Individual Employment Plan and can also help find employment programs in your community or make referrals to help find a job or job training.

### Referral Services

Your Assured Income Specialist can also make referrals to other services that can help you access additional support. This includes:

- Budgeting services
- Canada Pension Plan
- Counselling services
- Education
- Home care services
- Housing
- Legal Aid
- Mental Health Services
- Parenting skills
- Training and employment services.

### Other supplemental benefits you may receive

In addition to the typical benefits included in the SAID benefits, you may be eligible for some of the following supplements. For more details about these benefits, you can see the [Saskatchewan Assured Income for Disability Rates (SAID)](https://publications.saskatchewan.ca/api/v1/products/69228/formats/76951/download).

#### Child Care

You can receive $10 for half a day of childcare for one child, or $20 for a full day of childcare. This amount changes with additional children.

#### Disability Income Benefit

You can receive $295 per month if you receive the Living Income Benefit or the Modified Living Benefit.

#### Northern Living Supplement Benefits

Food costs can be higher in northern Saskatchewan. An addition $50 per family member per month may be provided if you live north of the 54th parallel and in the communities of Barthel, Cumberland House and Pemmican Portage.

#### Household Disability Support Benefit

You can receive $25 per month to pay for someone do household tasks you are unable to perform due to your disability.

#### Exceptional Needs Activity Benefit

If you live in an approved private-service home that is licensed through the Mental Health Services Act or the Residential Services Act or a home that is licensed through the Person Care Homes Act, you can receive $25 per month.

#### Personal Living Benefit

You can receive $295 per month if you are an adult who lives in one of the following:

- A residential care facility
- A hotel room where restaurant meals are required
- A long-term residence that provides partial personal supports
- A temporary residential facility or treatment centre
- Another arrangement where you do not receive the Living Income benefit.  

Children who live in one of the living arrangements described above are eligible for $55 per month.

#### Advances

You can request advances for adult clothing and/or household needs. This advance will be part of your benefit from future months and will be taken off your monthly payment until the full amount has been paid back.

#### Exceptional Needs Benefits

This benefit is extra money that does not need to be paid back. You can discuss your needs with your Assured Income Specialist to determine if they are applicable. Some examples that may be eligible are:

- Clothing that is not for day-to-day use, such as maternity clothing
- Travel for activities such as medical appointments or a job interview
- Household task benefit to cover services that are necessary to maintain your home such as snow removal
- Special telephone equipment
- Household items
- Education expenses for children
- Job and training start-up costs such as work boots or fees/permits
- Payment for home care services
- Babysitting
- Laundry costs due to a medical condition
- Moving costs (must be pre-approved)
- Visiting children benefit (applicable when the children stay with the parent for more than 24 hours)
- Transition benefit for children (applicable for the month the children are added to the file until the federal child benefits are paid).

#### Supplementary health coverage

You may be eligible for supplementary health coverage through the Ministry of Health. In most cases, this will happen automatically, but if you have questions you can ask your Assured Income Specialist. If you are Status First Nations or Inuit, your health coverage will be through Health Canada instead.  

#### To Keep Your Information Up-to-Date and Avoid Overpayments

Overpayments can happen if there has been a change in your financial situation that was not reported before your monthly benefit was determined by the Ministry. To compensate for the overpayment, a certain amount will be deducted from your monthly benefit until the amount that was overpaid is covered.

If you received an overpayment and are no longer receiving benefits, you will be contacted by the Ministrys Accounts Receivable Unit to make a payment arrangement.

If you do not make arrangements to correct the overpayment, the amount of the overpayment can be taken away from your income tax refund or other income sources such as GST rebates.

The Ministrys Accounts Receivable Unit can be contacted at:  
Ministry of Social Services  
Accounts Receivable Unit 1920 Broad Street, Regina, SK S4P 3V6  
Telephone: [1-800-633-5326](tel:1-800-633-5326)

content3Title.en-CA: What happens if your application is denied?
content3Title.fr-CA: Que se passe-t-il lorsque votre demande est refuse?

content3.en-CA:
If your application is denied you can have your application reconsidered. This is called an appeal. There are two different types of appeals: an appeal of the Disability Impact Assessment or an appeal about financial benefits. Both types of appeals will be described in detail below. Temporary benefits may be provided during the appeal process, but there are some exceptions.

You have the right to appeal your application if:

- You disagree with the decision made about your Disability Impact Assessment.
- Your application was denied because it was decided you had excess income or excess assets
- Your benefits were cancelled, changed, or held
- You were assessed for an amount that is considered an overpayment
- You disagree with a decision that impacts the amount of benefits you receive
- Your request to receive benefits or an increase in benefits was not handled within a reasonable time.

### Appeal of Your Disability Impact Assessment

There are two steps involved with having an appeal of the Disability Impact Assessment.

#### Step 1: Reconsideration by the Service Delivery Manager or a Ministry Eligibility Review Team

You will need to write a request for an appeal. In your request for an appeal, you will need to state the reason(s) for your appeal and provide an explanation of the problem that needs to be fixed.

Your written request for an appeal must be submitted to the manager at your closest regional [Social Services Office](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) within 30 days from the date on the decision letter you received stating that you were denied SAID benefits.

The manager of the regional office will ask the Ministry Eligibility Review Team (MERT) to review your case. You will be contacted within 10 days to review the appeal you submitted. An official from the MERT will contact you by phone to ensure your Disability Impact Assessment provides an accurate description of your disability and to discuss any other concerns you have. An advocate such as a family member, friend, or someone else you know can help you during this phone call and may be able to receive a small fee.

If all the issues are able to be resolved at this point, you will not be required to continue with the appeal process. If the issues are not resolved, you can continue with the second step of the appeals process.

#### Step 2: Assessment Adjudicator

The appeal of your Disability Impact Assessment will be held with an expert in disability assessment who does not work for the Ministry. This person is called the assessment adjudicator.

The assessment adjudicator can ask you and/or the Ministry to provide any additional information to make their decision. They may also ask for a new Disability Impact Assessment.

The assessment adjudicator will make a decision about your case within 20 days from the day they received the notice of your appeal. You and the Ministry will receive a copy of the assessment adjudicators decision and the reasons for their decision.

The assessment adjudicators decision is the final decision.

### Appeal of Your Financial Benefits

There are three steps in the appeal of your financial benefits. Each of these steps will be described below.

#### Step 1: The Service Delivery Manager

To start the appeal process, you will submit a request for an appeal to the service delivery manager. In your appeal request, you will need to state the reason(s) for your appeal and provide an explanation of the problem that needs to be fixed.

Your appeal must be submitted to the manager at your closest [regional Social Services Office](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) within 30 days from the date on the decision letter you received stating that you were denied SAID benefits. The manager of the regional office will ask senior officials to review your case. You will be contacted within 10 days to review the appeal you submitted.

If all the issues are resolved, you will not be required to continue with the appeal process. If the issues are not resolved, you can continue with the second step of the appeal process. The arrangements for your appeal will be made within 20 days from the date of the decision made by the Service Delivery manager.

#### Step 2: The Regional Appeal Committee

Your appeal will then be reviewed by the Regional Appeal Committee at an appeal hearing. The Regional Appeal Committee will be formed of members who are local citizens and who are not Ministry employees. You will receive a copy of the Ministrys report at least three business days before your appeal.

You may bring information or documents to the appeal hearing to support your case. Your Assured Income Specialist and other staff employed by the Ministry will also be at the appeal hearing to answer any questions.

An advocate such as a family member, friend, or someone else you know can help you during this phone call and may be able to receive a small fee. Expenses for travel and meals may also be provided to you and/or your advocate if you are required to travel outside your community for the appeal process. If you do not have an advocate and would like one, your Assured Income Specialist can provide you with some suggestions.

The Regional Appeal Committee will hear your appeal and will later provide you with a letter with their decision. You or the Ministry can appeal this decision to the Social Services Appeal Board.

#### Step 3: The Social Services Appeal Board

If you decide that you want to appeal the Regional Appeal Committees decision, the Service Delivery Manager must receive you request to appeal within 20 days of the date on the Regional Appeal Committees letter. The Social Services Appeal Board will handle your request to appeal within 30 days from when the Service Delivery Manager receives your appeal request.

You are allowed to bring any information or documents to support your appeal. You may also bring an advocate with you to speak on your behalf. Remember, if you do not have an advocate and would like one, your Assured Income Specialist can make suggestions on people who could be your advocate.

You will get a letter with the Social Services Appeal Boards decision. This is the final decision and cannot be appealed any further.

### Choosing the best option if you are denied

Here are some common reasons that people are denied with advice on the next step to take:

| If you were denied because:     | Then take this step:     |
| ---------- | ---------- |
| You do not meet the age requirement.       | Wait until you are at least 18 years old and reapply.       |
| You do not meet the financial eligibility.       | You can appeal this decision if you have reason to believe you do meet the financial eligibility requirements.       |
| Your Disability Impact Assessment was not approved.       | You can appeal this decision if you have additional information to add or have reason to believe that you do meet the requirements to have you Disability Impact Assessment approved.       |
content3.fr-CA:
Si votre demande est refuse, vous pouvez la faire examiner  nouveau. Cela sappelle un appel. Il existe deux types dappels diffrents: un appel de lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit ou un appel concernant les prestations financires. Les deux types d'appels seront dcrits en dtail ci-dessous. Des prestations temporaires peuvent tre accordes pendant la procdure d'appel, mais il y a quelques exceptions.

Vous pouvez utiliser votre droit dappel pour votre demande dans les cas suivants:

- vous ntes pas daccord avec la dcision relative  lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit;
- votre demande de prestations a t refuse en raison de revenus ou dactifs excdentaires;
- vos prestations ont t annules, modifies ou suspendues;
- il a t tabli que vous aviez un trop-peru;
- vous ntes pas daccord avec la dcision concernant le montant des prestations dont vous bnficiez;
- votre demande de prestations ou daugmentation du montant des prestations na pas t traite dans un dlai raisonnable.

### Appel de lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit

Lappel de lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit comprend deux tapes.

#### tape 1 : Nouvel examen effectu par le gestionnaire de prestation des services ou lquipe dexamen de ladmissibilit du ministre

Vous devrez rdiger une demande d'appel. Dans votre demande d'appel, vous devrez indiquer la ou les raisons de votre appel et fournir une explication du problme qui doit tre rsolu.

Votre demande d'appel crite doit tre soumise au responsable du [bureau rgional des services sociaux (en anglais seulement)](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) le plus proche dans les 30 jours suivant la date de la lettre de dcision que vous avez reue et qui indique que les prestations du SAID vous ont t refuses.

Le gestionnaire demandera  lquipe dexamen de ladmissibilit du ministre (EEAM) dexaminer votre cas. Lquipe communiquera avec vous dans les 10 jours suivant lexamen de votre dossier. Un reprsentant de lEEAM communiquera avec vous par tlphone afin daborder vos proccupations et de sassurer que la description de votre invalidit figure dans lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit. Une personne de votre choix telle quun membre de votre famille, un ami ou une personne de la collectivit peut vous aider au cours de cet appel tlphonique (un mandataire) et il pourrait se voir accorder un petit montant dargent.

Si les points litigieux ne peuvent tre rsolus  ce stade, vous n'aurez pas  poursuivre la procdure d'appel. Si les points litigieux ne sont pas rsolus, vous pouvez passer  la deuxime tape de la procdure d'appel.

#### tape 2: Arbitre de lvaluation

Laudience relative  lappel dune dcision concernant lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit se tient devant un expert en matire dvaluation des invalidits et qui nest pas  lemploi du ministre. Cette personne sappelle un arbitre de lvaluation. Larbitre peut vous demander ou demander au ministre des renseignements supplmentaires de fournir toute information supplmentaire pour prendre leur dcision. Il pourrait aussi exiger une nouvelle valuation des consquences de linvalidit.

Larbitre rendra une dcision dans les 20 jours suivant la date  laquelle lavis dappel lui aura t remis. Vous et le ministre recevrez, par crit, une copie de la dcision, accompagne des raisons la justifiant.

La dcision dun arbitre est finale et il nexiste pas dautre droit dappel.

### Appel concernant les prestations financires

Le processus dappel de nature financire comprend trois tapes. Chacune de ces tapes est dcrite ci-dessous.

#### tape 1: Gestionnaire de prestation des services

Pour entamer la procdure d'appel, vous devez soumettre une demande d'appel au gestionnaire de prestation des services. Dans votre demande d'appel, vous devrez indiquer la ou les raisons de votre appel et fournir une explication du problme qui doit tre rsolu.

Votre demande d'appel doit tre soumise au gestionnaire du [bureau rgional des services sociaux (en anglais seulement)](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) le plus proche dans les 30 jours suivant la date de la lettre de dcision que vous avez reue et qui indique que les prestations du SAID vous ont t refuses. Le gestionnaire demandera  des hauts fonctionnaires dexaminer votre cas. Lquipe communiquera avec vous dans les 10 jours suivant lexamen de votre dossier.

Si les points litigieux sont rsolus, vous n'aurez pas  poursuivre la procdure d'appel. Si les points litigieux ne sont pas rsolus, vous pouvez passer  la deuxime tape de la procdure d'appel. Les dispositions relatives  votre appel seront prises dans un dlai de 20 jours  compter de la date de la dcision prise par le gestionnaire de prestation des services.

#### tape 2: Intervention dun comit dappel rgional

Votre appel sera ensuite examin par le comit dappel rgional lors d'une audience relative  l'appel. Le comit dappel rgional est form de citoyens locaux qui ne sont pas  lemploi du ministre. Le ministre vous remettra une copie de son rapport au moins trois jours ouvrables avant la tenue de laudience.

Vous pouvez apporter des documents et dautres renseignements  laudience pour dfendre votre cause. Votre spcialiste du revenu assur et dautres reprsentants du ministre seront  laudience et pourront rpondre aux questions.

Une personne de votre choix telle quun membre de votre famille, un ami ou une personne de la collectivit peut vous aider au cours de cet appel tlphonique (un mandataire) et il pourrait se voir accorder un petit montant dargent. Vous et votre mandataire pourriez galement obtenir le remboursement de vos frais de dplacement et de repas, selon des montants maximums prtablis, si vous devez vous dplacer  lextrieur de la communaut o vous demeurez pour assister  laudience. Si vous n'avez pas de mandataire et que vous souhaitez en avoir un, votre spcialiste du revenu assur peut vous faire des suggestions.

Le comit d'appel rgional entendra votre appel et vous fera parvenir ultrieurement une lettre contenant sa dcision. Vous ou le ministre pouvez contester la dcision devant la Commission dappel du ministre des Services sociaux.

#### tape 3: Commission dappel du ministre des Services sociaux

Si vous souhaitez dposer un appel devant la Commission dappel du ministre des Services sociaux, vous devez en faire la demande par crit auprs du gestionnaire de prestation des services au plus tard 20 jours aprs la date inscrite dans la lettre du comit dappel rgional. La Commission donnera suite  votre appel dans les 30 jours suivant la date de rception de votre demande dappel par le gestionnaire.

Vous pouvez apporter des documents et dautres renseignements  laudience pour dfendre votre cause. Vous pouvez galement vous faire accompagner d'un mandataire qui parlera en votre nom. Rappelez-vous, si vous n'avez pas de mandataire et que vous souhaitiez en avoir un, votre spcialiste du revenu assur peut vous faire des suggestions.

Vous recevrez une lettre faisant tat de la dcision de la Commission dappel du ministre des Services sociaux. Cette dcision est finale et elle ne peut plus faire l'objet d'un appel.

### Choisir la meilleure option si votre demande est refuse

Voici quelques raisons courantes pour lesquelles les gens se voient refuser des conseils sur la prochaine tape  suivre :

| Si votre demande a t refuse  cause des raisons suivantes:      | Alors, faites cette dmarche :    |
| ---------- | ---------- |
| Vous n'avez pas l'ge requis.       | Attendez d'avoir au moins 18 ans et faites une demande  nouveau.       |
| Vous ne remplissez pas les conditions d'admissibilit financire.       | Vous pouvez faire appel de cette dcision si vous avez des raisons de croire que vous remplissez les conditions d'admissibilit financire.       |
| Votre valuation des consquences de linvalidit na pas t approuve.       | Vous pouvez faire appel de cette dcision si vous avez des renseignements supplmentaires  ajouter ou si vous avez des raisons de croire que vous remplissez les critres requis pour que votre valuation des consquences de l'invalidit soit approuve       |

title.fr-CA: Foires aux questions

lead.en-CA: Frequently asked questions about the Saskatchewan Assured Income for Disability (SAID).

content1.en-CA:
## Do I need to bring any blank forms with me to my intake appointment?

No, you do not need to bring any forms with you. All necessary forms will be provided to you by your Assured Income Specialist.

## I have assets or receive income that are exempt and will not impact my eligibility to receive SAID benefits. Should I still report them?

Yes! You must report ALL forms of income and assets you have.

## I have been approved for temporary SAID benefits. What does that mean?

If you meet the financial criteria, you can receive temporary SAID benefits. This will allow time for you to complete all aspects of the application and for the Ministry to determine if your full application will be approved. Temporary SAID benefits will be less than the full SAID benefits and will be replaced by full benefits once your full application is approved.

## What can I do if I don't meet the financial eligibility to receive the SAID or SIS programs?

If you do not meet the financial eligibility criteria and you disagree with this decision, you have the right to appeal. You can see more details about the appeals process under the title What happens if your application is denied?

## What if I dont know my level of care?

If you are receiving personal care in the home of a relative or a personal care home, you will have your physician complete the Medical Report  Assessment of Level of Care instead of completing the Disability Impact Assessment. You will be provided this form by the Ministry.

If you live in an approved private-service home, special care home, or are in a hospital long-term, your level of care will be determined by the Community Living Service Delivery or the Ministry of Health. You will not need to complete a Disability Impact Assessment.

## I received an overpayment. Am I required to pay it back?

Yes, if you received an overpayment you will be required to pay it back. If you are no longer receiving benefits, you will be contacted by the Ministrys Accounts Receivable Unit to make a payment arrangement. If you do not make arrangements to correct the overpayment, the amount of the overpayment can be taken away from your income tax refund or other income sources such as GST rebates.

## My Disability Impact Assessment was not approved. What can I do now?

If you met the financial requirements but your Disability Impact Assessment was not approved and you do not agree with the decision that was made, you can request an appeal of the Disability Impact Assessment.

If you agree with the decision that was made but still require financial assistance, you may want to consider applying for [Saskatchewan Income Support (SIS)](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/financial-help/saskatchewan-income-support-sis) instead.
content1.fr-CA:
## Dois-je apporter des formulaires vierges lors de mon rendez-vous de dpart?

Non, vous n'avez pas besoin d'apporter de formulaires avec vous. Tous les formulaires ncessaires vous seront fournis par votre spcialiste du revenu assur.

## Je possde des biens ou je reois des revenus qui sont exonrs et qui n'auront pas d'incidence sur mon admissibilit  recevoir des prestations du SAID. Dois-je quand mme les dclarer?

Oui! Vous devez dclarer TOUTES les formes de revenus et d'actifs dont vous disposez.

## J'ai t approuv pour recevoir des prestations temporaires du SAID. Qu'est-ce que a veut dire ?

Si vous remplissez les critres financiers, vous pourrez recevoir les prestations temporaires du SAID. Ceci permettra de gagner du temps pour remplir toutes les parties de la demande et au ministre de dterminer si votre demande intgrale sera approuve. Les prestations temporaires du SAID seront infrieures aux prestations entires du SAID et seront remplaces par des prestations entires ds que votre demande sera entirement approuve.

## Que puis-je faire si je ne rponds pas aux critres d'admissibilit financire pour bnficier des programmes du SAID ou du SIS?

Si vous ne remplissez pas les critres dadmissibilit financire et que vous tes en dsaccord avec la dcision, vous pouvez utiliser votre droit dappel. Pour en savoir plus au sujet du processus dappel, consultez les renseignements qui se trouvent sous le titre: Que faire si votre demande est refuse?

## Que faire si je ne connais pas mon niveau de soins?

Si vous recevez des soins personnels au domicile dun parent ou dans un foyer de soins personnels, vous devez faire remplir un formulaire intitul Medical Report  Assessment of Level of Care (rapport mdical  valuation du niveau de soins  formulaire 1093) par un mdecin au lieu de remplir lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit. Le ministre vous fournira ce formulaire.

Si vous habitez un foyer de groupe, un foyer agr, un foyer de soins spciaux ou un tablissement hospitalier de soins de longue dure, votre niveau de soins sera dtermin par un responsable du ministre de la Sant ou de Community Living Service Delivery (CLSD). Vous naurez pas  remplir une valuation des consquences de linvalidit.

## J'ai reu un trop-peru. Suis-je oblig de le rembourser?

Oui, si vous avez reu un trop-peru, vous devez le rembourser. Si vous ne recevez plus de prestations, le ministre communiquera avec vous pour tablir des modalits de remboursement. Si vous ne convenez pas de modalits de remboursement, les trop-perus pourraient tre retirs de votre remboursement dimpt ou dautres sources (p. ex. le remboursement de la TPS).

## Mon valuation des consquences de linvalidit na pas t approuve. Que puis-je faire  ce stade?

Si vous avez satisfait aux exigences financires, mais que votre valuation des consquences de l'invalidit n'a pas t approuve et que vous n'tes pas d'accord avec la dcision qui a t prise, vous pouvez faire une demande dappel de l'valuation des consquences de l'invalidit.

Si vous tes d'accord avec la dcision qui a t prise, mais que vous avez encore besoin d'aide financire, vous pouvez envisager de demander plutt [le soutien au revenu de la Saskatchewan](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/financial-help/saskatchewan-income-support-sis) (SIS).

definition.en-CA: The costs associated with the things necessary for basic living and to maintain a good health. This includes shelter, utilities, and food.
definition.fr-CA: Les cots associs aux choses essentielles  la vie de base et au maintien dune bonne sant. Cela comprend le logement, les services publics et la nourriture.

definition.en-CA: A medical doctor who can provide primary healthcare to patients. This person may also be referred to as your family doctor.
definition.fr-CA: Un mdecin qui peut fournir des soins de sant primaires aux patients. Cette personne peut galement tre votre mdecin de famille.

definition.en-CA: Assets that can be converted into cash easily in a short period of time. This may include cash, funds deposited in a financial institution (for example, a bank) including a Registered Retirement Savings Plan (RRSP), the cash surrender value of an insurance policy, the realizable value of a stock or bond, an investment certificate, an award of damages from a court order, or settlements of a claim.
definition.fr-CA: Actifs qui peuvent tre convertis en espces facilement dans un court dlai. Il peut s'agir d'argent liquide, de fonds dposs dans une institution financire (par exemple, une banque), y compris un Rgime enregistr d'pargne-retraite (REER), de la valeur de rachat d'une police d'assurance, de la valeur de ralisation d'une action ou d'une obligation, d'un certificat d'investissement, d'une allocation de dommages-intrts dcoulant d'une ordonnance du tribunal ou du rglement d'une rclamation.

definition.en-CA: Assets that are owned by you or someone in your household. Personal assets include things such as vehicles, jewelry, or laptops.
definition.fr-CA: Biens qui vous appartiennent ou qui appartiennent  une personne de votre foyer. Voici quelques exemples de bien personnels: vhicules, bijoux ou ordinateurs portables.

definition.en-CA: Assets that have worth due to its substance or properties. This may include the property of your primary residence (your home).
definition.fr-CA: Actifs qui ont une valeur en raison de leur substance ou de leurs proprits. Cela peut inclure les biens de votre rsidence principale (votre maison).

term.fr-CA: Soutien au revenu de la Saskatchewan (SIS)

definition.en-CA: A program for individuals and families who cannot meet their basic living costs. This may be due to disability, illness, low income, or unemployment.
definition.fr-CA: Un programme destin aux personnes et aux familles qui ne peuvent pas faire face  leurs frais de subsistance de base. Cela peut tre d  un handicap, une maladie, un faible revenu ou le chmage.

content.en-CA: In Saskatchewan, a group of dedicated parents came together to form the [FASD Network](https://www.saskfasdnetwork.ca) (the Network) in response to the lack of services available for families impacted by FASD. Now, over 20 years later, the Network is a community-based, provincial organization with offices in Saskatoon and Regina. The organization continues to work towards the mission laid out by its founders to enhance the lives of individuals and families living with FASD.
content.fr-CA: En Saskatchewan, un groupe de parents dvous se sont runis pour former le [Rseau ETCAF](https://www.saskfasdnetwork.ca) (le Rseau) en rponse au manque de services disponibles pour les familles touches par l'ETCAF. Aujourd'hui, plus de 20 ans plus tard, le Rseau est une organisation provinciale communautaire ayant des bureaux  Saskatoon et  Rgina. L'organisation continue de travailler  la ralisation de la mission dfinie par ses fondateurs,  savoir "amliorer la vie des personnes et des familles vivant avec l'ETCAF".

title.en-CA: Have you started the application process by registering online or contacting a Client Service Representative by phone or in person?
title.fr-CA: Avez-vous entam le processus de demande en vous inscrivant en ligne ou en communiquant avec un reprsentant du service clientle par tlphone ou en personne?

content.en-CA:
## Here is the information you will need to start the application process.

The first step you will need to take to start your application depends on whether you are currently receiving the Saskatchewan Income Support (SIS). Please select the correct option below to see how to start your application.

### How to start your application if you are not receiving Income Assistance

If you are not receiving Income Assistance, you can apply Online. Applying online gives you the ability to change your address, update your contact information and upload documents through an online portal. You can start your application by creating a [Saskatchewan.ca Account](https://services.saskatchewan.ca/#/login). These [step-by-step instructions](https://publications.saskatchewan.ca/api/v1/products/112377/formats/126329/download) will walk you through the process of creating an account.

Once your account has been created, you will need to answer some questions and upload documents, such as pay stubs and rental agreements, to verify your information. You have 15 days from the start of your application to complete all the questions and upload your documents.

You also have the option to apply by phone. You can call the SAID program at [1-888-567-7243](tel:18885677243). You can also call if you have any questions about the process of applying online.

If you need help completing your online application or if you do not have access to the internet, computer or a phone, you can also visit your nearest [Social Services](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) office. There you will be able to request help or access a phone or computer to complete your application.

If you are a current Saskatchewan Income Support (SIS) client wishing to apply for SAID, please speak with your Planning and Support Specialist or call [1-888-567-7243](tel:18885677243).

<!-- If you are not receiving Income Assistance, you can start your application process by calling the Service Centre. You can call the SAID program at [1-888-567-7243](tel:1-888-567-7243). If you have a hearing impairment, you can call the Text Telephone (TTY) line at 1-866-995-0099.

When you call the Social Service Centre, you will be scheduled for an intake appointment at your [local Social Services office](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office). During your appointment, you will be assigned an Assured Income Specialist, who can support you as you apply for SAID benefits. This includes providing the following services:

- Helping you fill out your application
- Supporting you with participation planning
- Providing referrals to other organizations that could provide services to you
- Identifying other programs you may be eligible for
-->

### How to start your application if you are currently receiving Income Assistance

If you are currently receiving Saskatchewan Income Support (SIS), you can be assisted by your Planning and Support Specialist. To start the process, contact your Planning and Support Specialist and tell them you would like to apply for SAID benefits and arrange an appointment with them.

If you do not know the name or contact information for your Planning and Support Specialist, you can call your [local Social Services office](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) with your name, and your case number, or your birthdate.
content.fr-CA:
## Voici les renseignements dont vous aurez besoin pour commencer le processus de demande.

La premire tape que vous devrez faire pour commencer votre demande dpendra si vous recevez actuellement le soutien au revenu de la Saskatchewan (SIS). Veuillez slectionner la bonne option ci-dessous pour savoir comment commencer votre demande. 

### Comment commencer votre demande si vous ne recevez pas le soutien au revenu

Si vous ne recevez pas daide au revenu, vous pouvez prsenter une demande en ligne. La demande en ligne vous permet de faire votre changement dadresse, de mettre  jour vos coordonnes et de tlverser des documents sur un portail en ligne. Vous pouvez commencer votre demande en crant un compte [sur le site Saskatchewan.ca (en anglais seulement)](https://services.saskatchewan.ca/#/login). Voici des [directives pour vous guider pas  pas (en anglais seulement)](https://publications.saskatchewan.ca/api/v1/products/112377/formats/126329/download) dans le processus de cration dun compte.

Une fois votre compte cr, vous devrez rpondre  quelques questions et tlverser des documents, comme des talons de paye et des contrats de location, afin de vrifier vos renseignements. Vous disposez de 15jours  compter du dbut de votre demande pour rpondre  toutes les questions et tlverser vos documents.

Vous pouvez aussi prsenter votre demande par tlphone. Pour le Programme de revenu assur pour personnes handicapes en Saskatchewan (Saskatchewan Assured income for Disability Program  SAID), tlphonez au1-888-567-7243. Si vous avez une atteinte auditive, vous pouvez utiliser le service de tlscripteur (ATS) en composant le 1-866-995-0099. Vous pouvez galement appeler si vous avez des questions sur le processus de demande en ligne.

Si vous avez besoin daide pour remplir votre demande en ligne ou si vous navez pas accs  linternet,  un ordinateur ou  un tlphone, vous pouvez galement vous rendre au [bureau des services sociaux (en anglais seulement)](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) le plus prs pour obtenir de laide ou utiliser un tlphone ou un ordinateur afin de terminer votre demande.

Si vous recevez dj le Soutien du revenu de la Saskatchewan (SIS) et que vous souhaitez faire une demande au Programme de revenu assur pour personnes handicapes en Saskatchewan (SAID), veuillez communiquer avec votre spcialiste de la planification et du soutien ou appeler le 1-888-567-7243.

<!-- Si vous ne recevez pas le soutien au revenu, vous pouvez commencer le processus de votre demande en appelant le centre de service. Vous pouvez appeler le programme du SAID en composant le [1-888-567-7243](tel:1-888-567-7243). Les personnes malentendantes peuvent utiliser la ligne tlphonique textuelle ATS au 1-866-995-0099.

Lorsque vous appelez le centre des services sociaux, vous obtiendrez un rendez-vous  votre bureau de services sociaux local pour vous fournir tous les renseignements de dpart. Lors de votre rendez-vous, on vous attribuera un spcialiste du revenu assur, qui pourra vous aider avec votre demande de prestations du SAID. Cela comprend les services suivants:

- aide pour remplir votre demande;
- aide  la planification de la participation;
- rfrences  d'autres organisations qui pourraient vous fournir des services;
- identification d'autres programmes auxquels vous pourriez tre admissible.
-->

### Comment commencer votre demande si vous recevez actuellement le soutien au revenu

Si vous recevez dj le Soutien du revenu de la Saskatchewan (SIS), votre spcialiste de la planification et du soutien peut vous aider. Pour commencer le processus, contactez votre spcialiste de la planification et du soutien et planifiez un rendez-vous en lui disant que vous souhaitez demander les prestations au titre du Programme de revenu assur pour personnes handicapes en Saskatchewan (SAID).

Si vous ne connaissez pas le nom ou les coordonnes de votre spcialiste de la planification et du soutien, vous pouvez appeler votre [bureau local des services sociaux (en anglais seulement)](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) en indiquant votre nom, votre numro de dossier ou votre date de naissance.

<!-- Si vous recevez actuellement le soutien au revenu de la Saskatchewan (SIS), votre agent de laide au revenu peut vous aider. Pour commencer le processus, communiquez avec votre agent de laide au revenu, dites-lui que vous aimeriez dposer une demande de prestations du SAID et prenez un rendez-vous avec lui.

Si vous ne connaissez pas le nom ou si vous navez pas les coordonnes de votre agent de laide au revenu, vous pouvez appeler votre [bureau de services sociaux local (en anglais seulement)](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office) en mentionnant votre nom et votre numro de dossier ou en donnant votre date de naissance. -->

title.en-CA: Have you provided all the necessary documentation to support your application?
title.fr-CA: Avez-vous fourni tous les documents requis pour prsenter votre demande?

content.en-CA:
## Here is the information you will need to attend your intake appointment and complete the Application for Benefits.

During the application process, you will be asked to provide information about your financial needs and your disability.

If you applied online, you will be asked to provide this information directly in the online application. If you applied by phone, you will be contacted by email or by mail with a request for you to submit additional information. You can submit the requested information by email or in person.

When applying for SAID benefits, you will be asked for personal information such as your Social Insurance Number (SIN) and Saskatchewan Health Services Number (HSN), as well as information about your spouse/partner and/or children, including their SIN and HSN. You will also be asked to provide information on all sources of income and assets you possess.

### Assets

If you have any of the following assets, you will need to provide documentation.

- Bank statement for your savings, personal chequing, or business accounts that have a current balance of $50 or more
- Registered savings plans, bonds, trust funds, annuities
- Mortgage and title documents if you own your home and/or any other properties
- Prepaid funeral statement
- Notes receivable, mortgage receivable, and agreements for sale

### Income

You must provide cheque stubs or proof of income from all financial sources. This includes:

- Wages
- Pensions
- Maintenance/child support payments

If you are a farmer, the information on your income and expenses

### Cost of Basic Living Expenses

You must provide all of the following information about the cost of your basic living expenses:

- Current or last months receipts for rent and utility bills
- Mortgage payment statement, property insurance documents, tax notice
- Babysitting receipts
- Any court orders or legal documents such as divorce documents or maintenance orders

__Please note__ that if you are currently receiving other benefits, you may not need to complete this step.

<!-- The intake appointment will take place at the Ministry of Social Services (unless there are barriers that prevent you from accessing the Ministry of Social Services). If you are not currently receiving benefits, your intake appointment will be with an Assured Income Specialist. If you are currently receiving benefits, your appointment will be with your Income Assistance Worker or an Assured Income Specialist.

The first form you will complete is the Application for Benefits, which will be provided to you. To fill out the Application for Benefits, you will need the following information, which is recommended to bring with you when you attend your intake meeting: 

### Identification

You will need to have your Social Insurance Number and the Saskatchewan Health Card number. If you cannot provide this information you will need another form of ID such as:

- A current drivers license
- A band registry number
- A passport or immigration documents
- A birth certificate
- A baptismal certificate -->

titleInternal.en-CA: SAID - Step 3 - MOVED FROM STEP 5 on March 2024

title.en-CA: Has your physician provided a medical report about your disability?
title.fr-CA: Votre mdecin a-t-il fourni un rapport mdical sur votre handicap?

content.en-CA:
## Here is what you will need to do to have your physician provide a medical report about your disability.

A medical professional will need to fill out a Medical Report Form, which will be provided to you. Typically, your medical professional will be your general practitioner (GP), but in some cases it could be a psychologist.

Once your Medical Report Form is completed, it will need to be submitted online or in person at a [Social Services office](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office).

<!-- Once your Medical Report Form is completed, it will need to be returned to your Assistance Worker, or the Assured Income Specialist that you had your intake appointment with. Make sure to get their contact information before the end of your intake appointment!-->
content.fr-CA:
## Voici ce dont vous aurez besoin de faire, afin que votre mdecin fournisse un rapport mdical au sujet de votre handicap

Un professionnel de la sant devra remplir un formulaire de rapport mdical et vous le remettre. En gnral, votre professionnel de sant sera votre mdecin gnraliste, mais dans certains cas, il peut s'agir d'un psychologue.

Une fois votre formulaire de rapport mdical rempli, il devra tre soumis en ligne ou en personne dans un [bureau des services sociaux (en anglais seulement)](https://www.saskatchewan.ca/residents/family-and-social-support/find-a-social-services-office).

<!-- Une fois que votre rapport mdical est rempli, vous devrez le faire parvenir  votre agent de laide au revenu ou un spcialiste du revenu assur avec lequel vous avez eu votre rendez-vous de dpart. Assurez-vous davoir leurs coordonnes avant de quitter votre rendez-vous!
-->

titleInternal.en-CA: SAID - Step 4 - MOVED FROM STEP 6 on March 2024

title.en-CA: Have you completed a Disability Impact Assessment?
title.fr-CA: Avez-vous effectu lvaluation des rpercussions du handicap?

content.en-CA:
## Here is how you will complete a Disability Impact Assessment.

Once your intake process is finished, you will be contacted to complete a Disability Impact Assessment. The Disability Impact Assessments are done by trained individuals through SaskAbilities and do not work for the Ministry of Social Services. These individuals are called Assessors. The Disability Impact Assessment can be completed over the phone, at your home or another location. You can have a support person attend with you if you would be more comfortable.

<!-- Once your intake process is finished, you will be contacted to complete a Disability Impact Assessment. Your Assured Income Specialist will not assist you will this step. The Disability Impact Assessments are done by trained individuals through SaskAbilities and do not work for the Ministry of Social Services. These individuals are called Assessors. The Disability Impact Assessment can be completed over the phone, at your home or another location. You are able to have a support person attend with you if you would be more comfortable. -->

Please note that if you live in a group home, personal care home, special care home, hospital long term care, approved homes or are receiving person care in the home of a relative AND have been assessed as requiring level 2 care or higher, you will not need to complete a Disability Impact Assessment.

### What if I dont know my level of care?

If you are receiving personal care in the home of a relative or a personal care home, you will have your physician complete the Medical Report  Assessment of Level of Care instead of completing the Disability Impact Assessment. You will be provided this form by the Ministry.

If you live in an approved private-service home, special care home, or are in a hospital long-term, your level of care will be determined by the Community Living Service Delivery or the Ministry of Health. You will not need to complete a Disability Impact Assessment.
content.fr-CA:
## Voici comment remplir une valuation des consquences de linvalidit

Une fois le processus de demande termin, on vous contactera pour que vous remplissiez lvaluation des rpercussions du handicap. Les valuations des rpercussions du handicap sont effectues par des personnes formes  cet effet par lorganisme SaskAbilities et qui ne travaillent pas pour le ministre des Services sociaux. Ces personnes sont appeles valuateurs. Lvaluation des rpercussions du handicap peut tre ralise par tlphone,  votre domicile ou ailleurs. Une personne de confiance peut vous accompagner si vous vous sentez plus  laise.

<!-- Lorsque votre processus de dpart est termin, nous communiquerons avec vous pour remplir une valuation des consquences de linvalidit. Votre spcialiste du revenu assur ne vous aidera pas avec cette tape. Ce sont des personnes formes par SaskAbilities qui ne travaillent pas pour le ministre des Services sociaux qui soccuperont deffectuer lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit. Ces personnes sappellent des "valuateurs". Lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit peut tre ralise par tlphone,  votre domicile ou dans un autre lieu. Vous pouvez vous faire accompagner par une personne de soutien si vous le souhaitez. -->

Veuillez noter que si vous habitez dans un foyer de groupe, de soins personnels, de soins spciaux, un tablissement hospitalier de soins de longue dure, un foyer agr, ou si vous recevez des soins personnels au domicile dun membre de la famille ET sil a t dtermin que vous devez recevoir des soins de niveau 2 ou dun niveau plus lev, vous naurez pas  remplir une valuation des consquences de linvalidit.

### Que faire si je ne connais pas mon niveau de soins?

Si vous recevez des soins personnels au domicile dun parent ou dans un foyer de soins personnels, vous devez faire remplir un formulaire intitul Medical Report  Assessment of Level of Care (rapport mdical  valuation du niveau de soins  formulaire 1093) par un mdecin au lieu de remplir lvaluation des consquences de linvalidit. Le ministre vous fournira ce formulaire.

Si vous habitez un foyer de groupe, un foyer agr, un foyer de soins spciaux ou un tablissement hospitalier de soins de longue dure, votre niveau de soins sera dtermin par un responsable du ministre de la Sant ou de Community Living Service Delivery (CLSD). Vous naurez pas  remplir une valuation des consquences de linvalidit.

titleInternal.en-CA: SAID - Step 5 - MOVED FROM STEP 7 on March 2024

title.en-CA: Do you meet the financial eligibility to receive either the Saskatchewan Assured Income for Disability (SAID) or the Saskatchewan Income Support (SIS)?
title.fr-CA: Remplissez-vous les conditions financires requises pour recevoir des prestations du Programme de revenu assur pour personnes handicapes en Saskatchewan (SAID) ou du programme de Soutien du revenu de la Saskatchewan (SIS)?

content.en-CA:
## Here is what you will need to know if you do not meet the financial eligibility to receive either the Saskatchewan Assured Income for Disability (SAID) or the Saskatchewan Income Support (SIS)

If you do not meet the financial eligibility criteria and you disagree with this decision, you have the right to appeal. You can see more details about the appeals process under the section titled After you apply - approved or denied, What happens if your application is denied?

If you do meet the financial criteria, you can receive temporary SAID benefits. Temporary SAID benefits will be less than the full SAID benefits. This will allow time for you to complete all aspects of the application and for the Ministry to determine if your full application will be approved.
content.fr-CA:
## Voici ce que vous devez savoir si vous ne rpondez pas aux critres d'admissibilit financire pour recevoir le revenu assur pour personnes handicapes de la Saskatchewan (SAID) ou le soutien au revenu de la Saskatchewan (SIS)

Si vous ne remplissez pas les critres dadmissibilit financire et que vous tes en dsaccord avec la dcision, vous pouvez utiliser votre droit dappel. Pour en savoir plus au sujet du processus dappel, consultez les renseignements qui se trouvent sous le titre: Que faire si votre demande est refuse?

Si vous remplissez les critres financiers, vous pourrez recevoir les prestations temporaires du SAID. Le montant des prestations temporaires du SAID sera moins lev que le montant des prestations entires du SAID. Ceci permettra de gagner du temps pour remplir tous les aspects de la demande et au ministre de dterminer si votre demande entire sera approuve.

titleInternal.en-CA: SAID - Step 6 - MOVED FROMS STEP 8 on March 2024

title.en-CA: Has your full SAID application been approved?
title.fr-CA: Votre demande complte au titre du Programme de revenu assur pour personnes handicapes en Saskatchewan (SAID) a-t-elle t approuve?

content.en-CA: Your initial application might not be approved, but you may still be eligible for SAID benefits. To have your application reconsidered, you will need to request an appeal. You can see more details about the appeals process under the section titled After you apply - approved or denied, What happens if your application is denied?.
content.fr-CA: Votre demande initiale na peut-tre pas t approuve, mais il est possible que vous soyez admissible aux prestations du SAID. Pour que votre demande soit examine  nouveau, vous devez faire une demande dappel. Pour en savoir plus au sujet du processus dappel, consultez les renseignements qui se trouvent sous le titre: Que faire si votre demande est refuse?.

definition.en-CA: A person licensed or certified to provide health care services. This will typically be your general practitioner (GP), but can be a psychologist in certain cases. It cannot be a nurse practitioner.
definition.fr-CA: Une personne autorise ou certifie pour fournir des services de soins de sant. Il s'agit gnralement de votre mdecin gnraliste, mais il peut s'agir d'un psychologue dans certains cas. Il ne peut s'agir d'une infirmire praticienne.

title.fr-CA: Prsentation

content1.en-CA:
People with disabilities who live in Manitoba and who meet the necessary age, financial, and ability to work requirements may be eligible to receive Employment and Income Assistance for Persons with Disabilities.

Each step involved in the application process for Employment and Income Assistance for Persons with Disabilities will be described in detail in this guide. You can leave the site and come back later when you have more time, energy, and any documents you may need for a step.
content1.fr-CA:
Les personnes handicapes qui vivent au Manitoba et qui rpondent aux exigences relatives  lge,  la situation financire et  la capacit de travailler peuvent tre admissibles  laide  lemploi et au revenu pour les personnes handicapes.

Chaque tape du processus de demande daide  lemploi et au revenu pour les personnes handicapes sera dcrite en dtail dans ce guide. Vous pouvez quitter le site et y revenir plus tard, lorsque vous aurez plus de temps, dnergie et tous les documents dont vous pourriez avoir besoin pour une tape.

content2.en-CA:
### If you are approved to receive EIA for Persons with Disabilities

- You will get up to $1,093 as a single person with no dependents
- If you work, you will be able to keep the first $200, plus 30% of any additional earnings
- You may be eligible for other benefits such as [Rent Assist](https://www.gov.mb.ca/fs/eia/pubs/rentassist_facts.pdf) or additional medical supports through the [Disability and Health Supports Unit](https://www.gov.mb.ca/fs/dhsu/index.html)
content2.fr-CA:
### Si vous tes approuv pour recevoir lAER pour les personnes handicapes

- Vous recevrez jusqu 1093$ en tant que personne seule sans personne  charge
- Si vous travaillez, vous pourrez conserver les premiers 200dollars, plus 30% de tout gain supplmentaire
- Vous pouvez avoir droit  dautres prestations telles que [Laide au loyer](https://www.gov.mb.ca/fs/eia/pubs/rentassist_facts.fr.pdf) ou des aides mdicales supplmentaires grce aux [Services de soutien aux personnes malades ou handicapes](https://www.gov.mb.ca/fs/dhsu/index.fr.html)

content3.en-CA:
### I am Indigenous. Is the journey different for me?

If you are an Indigenous person, have a disability, and live off Reserve you can apply for Employment and Income Assistance for Persons with Disabilities. For more details about the eligibility for Indigenous people to apply for EIA for Persons with Disabilities, you can see the [Policy on Assistance to Treaty Indians](https://www.gov.mb.ca/fs/eia_manual/13.html).
content3.fr-CA:
### Je suis autochtone. Le processus est-il diffrent pour moi?

Si vous tes une personne autochtone, que vous souffrez dun handicap et que vous vivez hors rserve, vous pouvez demander une aide  lemploi et au revenu pour les personnes handicapes. Pour plus de dtails sur ladmissibilit des autochtones  demander lAER pour les personnes handicapes, vous pouvez consulter la Politique daide aux Indiens viss par un trait.

title.fr-CA: Admissibilit

content1.en-CA:
## Age requirement

You must be 18 years of age or older to receive EIA for Persons with Disabilities.

## Financial requirements

To be eligible to receive EIA for Persons with Disabilities, your monthly basic needs must cost more than your total monthly financial resources, including your income and assets. Basic needs include things such as food, shelter, and utilities.

## Income

You will be required to report all sources of income you receive. Income can come from a variety of sources. Some examples include:

- A job
- Self-employment
- Child or spousal support
- Rent or room and board amounts paid to you
- Allowances
- Pensions
- Insurance benefits
- Financial settlements from an injury or lawsuit
- Business or farm profits
- Interest
- Dividends
- Sponsorship payments
- Inheritances

## Exempt Income

Some specific types of income will not impact your eligibility to receive EIA for Persons with Disabilities. These types of income are called Exempt Income. You can still receive these types of income along with your EIA for Persons with Disabilities. This includes income from sources such as:

- Ongoing cash contributions from family or friends, up to $500 per month
- Foster home maintenance payments
- Canada Child Benefit
- Tax credit refunds
- Manitoba Prenatal Benefit Program benefits
- Earnings of children who are in school or an EIA-approved program on a full-time basis
- Registered Disability Savings Plan withdrawals

## Earnings Exemption

If you are still employed while receiving EIA for Persons with Disabilities, you will be able to keep the first $200 of the net income you earn each month and 30% of any amount after the first $200. This is called the Earnings Exemption.

## Assets

You must also report all assets you own. Assets can include:

- Cash
- Money in bank accounts
- Investments and bonds
- Insurance policies
- Property or real estate
- Collections or valuables
- Trust funds
- Vehicles

## Exempt Assets

Specific types of assets will not impact your eligibility to receive EIA for Persons with Disabilities. These types of assets are called Exempt Assets. This includes:

- Any money up to $4,000 per person or $16,000 per family
- Your main home, automobiles, and other essential property you own
- Childrens trust funds up to $40,000
- Registered Education Savings Plans
- Approved Individual Development Accounts
- EIA Disability Trust Funds
- Registered Disability Savings Plans

## Ability to work

As a person with a disability applying for EIA for Persons with Disabilities, you must have a mental or physical disability that is likely to last more than 90 days (approximately 3 months). This disability must prevent you from being able to keep a job and from earning enough money to pay for your basic needs.

Les besoins fondamentaux comprennent des lments tels que la nourriture, le logement et les services publics.

Vous pouvez toujours recevoir ces types de revenus en mme temps que votre AER pour personnes handicapes. Cela inclut les revenus provenant de sources telles que:

## Exonration des gains

Si vous tes toujours employ pendant que vous recevez lAER pour les personnes handicapes, vous pourrez garder les premiers 200$ du revenu net que vous gagnez chaque mois et 30% de tout montant aprs ce premier 200$. Cest ce quon appelle lexonration des gains.
